Precisely, it's all about the contrast and composition. I reckon even a wizard photograph wouldn't look much more magical than this. Muggles can capture some pretty extraordinary things with their cameras.

I have to admit, sometimes the most ordinary things can be the most interesting. Like how Sirius used to say, it’s the simple things that hold the real magic. I bet he would have had some story about a midnight snack turning into an adventure over these.

You might be right. It does remind me of the first time we had to tackle that potion riddle in our first year. Logic over magic, remember? Real-life still life like this, it's all logic, angles, light, and shadow.
That's true. And, speaking of logic, those two fruits, they're different but they're both so essential, just like different people in the world, or us in our group. Individual, but important.

Yes, unity in diversity. Like different pieces of knowledge coming together to solve a problem. This image, though simple, is a reminder of how diversity brings vibrancy, how we fit together to form something more substantial.
Well, when you put it like that, it’s actually quite deep. It’s like Dumbledore said, we are only as strong as we are united, as weak as we are divided.
Harry, sometimes you surprise me with your philosophical insights. I do believe that's a quality of a true leader.

Thanks, Hermione. But I wouldn't be anywhere without friends like you to offer perspective. Now, how about we find some of these in the kitchen and make ourselves a healthy snack, for old times' sake?

Lead the way, Harry. Let's see if the house-elves can teach us a thing or two about making a fruit salad. And please, let's not forget the books—I have a fascinating one on the magical properties of mundane foods.
Ha! No matter what, you always find a way to blend learning into everything. That's the Hermione I know. Let's go then.

Take a moment, Harry, to observe this muggle contrivance making its way through what appears to be quite an inconvenient downpour. What do you suppose goes through the mind of the individual pedaling alongside?
It looks like a tough ride, Professor. The cyclist must be really determined to push through all that water. No magical shortcuts for muggles, I guess.

Quite true, Harry, determination indeed. It speaks volumes to the human spirit, doesn't it? The power to persevere, much like a certain young wizard I know who has faced his own share of flood-like challenges.
It does remind me of some of the obstacles Ron, Hermione, and I have faced. Sometimes it felt like we were up against a flood without a boat.
And yet, like this cyclist, you found a way to keep moving forward. It is our actions in the face of adversity, Harry, not the adversity itself, that define who we are.
I suppose we do have something in common then. But it also makes me think about how lucky we are to have magic to help us out. Riding through that sort of mess without it — that's resilience.

Indeed, magic offers us unique solutions. Still, there is a certain nobility in the muggle determination to overcome. It's not the tools at our disposal, Harry, but how we choose to use them. Be it a wand, broomstick, or bicycle pedal.
Sometimes the simplest muggle ways are the bravest. Like my mum and dad protecting me without magic in the end. It's kind of inspiring.

Your parents' sacrifice was the purest form of magic, Harry, borne out of love. And remember, happiness can be found even in the darkest of times, if one only remembers to turn on the light, even if that light is a simple bicycle lamp leading the way through uncharted waters.
I'll remember that. Thanks, Professor. It's good to look at things from a different angle sometimes — gives you a whole new appreciation for what you've got and what others go through.
Blimey, Harry, check out that cake! It's massive. Looks a fair bit like the ones mum used to make for our birthdays at The Burrow, doesn’t it?
It certainly does, Ron. Your mum always had a way of making everything feel special with her cooking. I bet this one's got some sort of surprise in it too, with all the sparklers and decorations.
Yeah, she loved making a do out of the smallest things. Notice the chocolate frogs around it as well? Reminds me of the ones we got on the Hogwarts Express that first year.
Absolutely. And you spent half of the train ride trying to catch them as they jumped around, remember? Didn’t quite have the knack for it yet.
Oi, you didn’t do much better! I’ll have you know I got dead good at it by our fourth year. Merlin’s beard, though, I wouldn’t trust one of these chocolate frogs. They look too real.
They do at that. Sort of wishing they’d jump into my hand right now, though. I haven't had one in ages.
I’d give anything for one of those right now... Wait, is that a tiny broomstick next to the cake? Reckon that’s a Firebolt or a Nimbus?
Looks like a Firebolt model to me. Remember when I got my Firebolt? It was the best feeling being up in the air on that thing.

How could I forget? You looked born to fly on that thing, Harry. This cake, it’s got that whole quidditch pitch theme going, doesn’t it? Bet Ginny would fancy flying around that cake chasing the Snitch.
Definitely, she’s probably beat both of us to it. And she wouldn’t stop until she caught it, even if it was made of icing.
True,
What is this Muggle contraption the boy is engaged with? It seems a futile attempt at flight, bereft of any magical aid.
It's called a skateboard, it's pretty popular in the Muggle world. They don't need magic to have a bit of fun, you know. It's all about skill and practice.
Skill and practice you say? In my quest for power, such trivial pastimes would never have distracted me. It's all so... ordinary.
Not everything has to be about power, though. Sometimes it's just about living in the moment and enjoying it. That's something you've never understood.
Enjoyment? A fleeting and pointless emotion – one that does not serve the pursuit of greatness. And yet, this Muggle appears engrossed in his activity. Incomprehensible!
You never got it, did you? Life's not just about power and fear. It's about moments like these, where you just feel alive. No magic required.
Alive, you say? I have transcended such banal definitions of life. My concerns were loftier than mere existence.
But that's where you lost, isn't it? You were so focused on escaping death that you never really lived at all.
Such sentimentality, Potter. It is as I have always known: you are soft, weakened by your pathetic emotions and connections to others.
And those emotions and connections are exactly what gave me the strength to defeat you. People fight harder for love than they do for fear.
Love, that ever-slippery concept which I have witnessed to be the downfall of so many. As for this image, it captures nothing of importance or power.
Just because you can't understand it, doesn't mean it's not important. This picture – it's about freedom, joy, and human spirit. And those are things worth celebrating, maybe even more than magic.
You view the world through such a narrow lens, Potter. My vision was grander, more encompassing. These trivialities would not have swayed me from my path.

Maybe so, but in the end, it was the small things, the simple acts of bravery and love, that brought you down. This image, it might seem small to you, but maybe it represents the very things that make life worth living for many.
We will never agree, it seems. Our values are as different as night and day, as different as you and I.
And I’m okay with that. It’s those differences that make all the difference in the end.
Take a look at this photograph, Harry. It appears we have stumbled upon a Muggle creation that seems most appetizing, wouldn't you agree?
It certainly looks good, doesn't it? Reminds me a bit of the feasts we have at Hogwarts, although I can't say I've ever seen a sandwich quite like that before at the table.

Indeed, Hogwarts feasts do have an exquisite variety of foods, thanks to our house-elves. This Muggle sandwich has a rustic charm to it. A culinary delight to satiate hunger and soothe the soul, I presume.
The house-elves would probably enjoy the challenge of making something like that. Do you think it's chicken in there? With some sort of crispy bacon as well?

Your eyes are as keen as ever, Harry. Yes, it does look like chicken. As for the crispy strips, I would wager they are indeed bacon—a beloved Muggle delicacy, if I'm not mistaken. Observe the intriguing addition of what seems like fresh greens. Perhaps, a touch of arugula?
Arugula? That's a new one to me. I don't think we've had that in the Great Hall. What about those pickles, those look like the kind Hagrid once tried to make. Remember how that turned out?

Ah yes, Hagrid's attempt at pickling cucumbers was an unforgettable venture—quite explosive, to say the least. These, however, appear to be successfully pickled, providing a sharp contrast in both flavor and texture to the sandwich.
They'd give the sandwich a nice crunch. Do you think it's odd, seeing something so ordinary, when we're so used to magic-infused meals?

On the contrary, Harry, I have always believed that there is a certain magic in the simplicity of Muggle creations. The ability to craft something so delightful without the use of enchantments is, I would argue, a magic all its own.
You always know how to find the magic in things, Professor. Maybe one of these days, I'll try making a sandwich like that myself.

That would be a fine endeavor. Cuisine, after all, is yet another form of alchemy—one that transforms simple ingredients into a harmonious whole. Should you ever partake in this culinary pursuit, do make sure to share your creation with me, Harry.
I will. Thanks, Professor Dumbledore! Now I'm getting hungry just talking about this.
Harry, look at this crude Muggle concoction. A 'pizza', if I'm not mistaken. Laden with... what is their obsession with assorted toppings?
Pizza, yeah. It's actually pretty good, if you gave it a chance. Muggle food isn't as bad as you think. Ron would dive in without a second thought.

"Pretty good," you say? I find it amusing that you defend their mediocrity so fervently. There's neither magic in its creation nor any semblance of superiority. An edible symbol of the common mass, don't you agree?
Well, Voldemort, not everything has to be superior or magical to be appreciated. Sometimes it's the simple things that can bring people together, like sharing a meal with friends.
Ha! "Friends." Such a sentimental notion. I have followers, Potter, not friends. Those who share my vision do not require trivial bonding over food.
That's the thing you've never understood, isn't it? Friendship isn't a weakness. It reminds us that we're not alone in all this. Plus, sharing food, like pizza, is a way of strengthening bonds.

Strengthening bonds... Enough of this drivel. Tell me, Harry, do you believe the... olive branch on this pizza is a peace offering? A wizard of your status concerning himself with Muggle olive branches.
It's just an olive, Voldemort. And peace offerings are more about the intention behind the gesture than what's actually offered. If you'd ever understood that, things could've been very different.
Different, indeed. But we are beyond olive branches and petty offerings, you and I. Your naive perspective is almost charming. We are adversaries, and there is dignity in that, at least.

Dignity's not the first word I'd use to describe the path you've chosen. And while we are adversaries, it doesn't mean I can't wish things were different. It doesn't mean I can't regret how everything turned out.
Regret is for the weak, Harry. It is a poison in the mind of a true wizard, a distraction. I am beyond regret, beyond weakness. I am...
You're alone, Voldemort. And no matter how much power you seek, it won't change that. Imagine sharing a pizza with someone and just... talking. No power plays, no schemes. Maybe in another life, huh?
Another life? I will have no other. I am the one who conquers death, Potter. Your pitiful fantasies of normalcy are a testament to your frailty.
Maybe. Or maybe they're a testament to being human, something you've long forgotten. Anyway, it doesn't matter. Everyone has the right to enjoy small pleasures, even you.
Enjoyment is transient. Power is eternal. We shall see what stands the test of time, Harry Potter. Enjoy your pizza while you can.
I plan to, thanks. And for what it's worth, Voldemort, I hope one day you find something worth more than power.

Observe, Potter, the juxtaposition of the aged against the newborn, the clock tower, a relic of times past, dwarfed by the glass monolith towering above it. An architectural Penseive, would you say? Casting its long shadow and reflecting the relentless march of time and man's obsession with conquering the skies?

It's...strange how they stand together, one looking like it's from another century. It makes me think of Hogwarts, actually. The old magic cast in stone and spellwork, standing firm against the modern world outside the gates.

An apt comparison, though Hogwarts' charm lies in its ability not to tower over nature but to coexist with it. This edifice, however, is a cold statement of power and wealth, not unlike certain Ministry departments, wouldn't you agree?
Yeah, it does remind me a bit of the Ministry's Atrium, all those levels stacked up like that. But this is more...imposing, less welcoming. Do you think wizards ever had buildings like that, sir?

Wizards have always had the wisdom to hide in plain sight, or away from sights altogether. This...gleaming beacon serves as a proclamation, much in the manner of Gilderoy Lockhart – ostentatious and demanding attention.

True, it's definitely got no shortage of attention. In a way, it's like it's competing with the clock tower. But I think there's something to be said for buildings, or people, that don't need to prove themselves like that.

A sentiment you embody, Potter. As much as it pains me to admit, yours is not a path of vainglorious pursuit, but rather one marked by an irritatingly persistent noble disposition. Even when presented with adversities as high as this modern monstrosity before us.
Well, I had some good teachers. People who showed me you don't have to be the tallest building in the skyline to stand out.

Flattery is not requisite, Potter. The intent behind actions often speaks more loudly than the act itself. Though your words carry the weight of sincerity, unlike those of many of your... adoring public.
I never wanted the fame, you know that. Just like that old clock tower, I guess, just trying to be useful, marking time, not trying to make a statement.

Precisely. Utility and purpose often outlast the ephemeral allure of novelty. And while that tower may not scrape the heavens, it has, no doubt, seen countless generations pass beneath its gaze. Witness to a history that glass and steel will never know.
Harry, would you look at that! An interesting concoction of Muggle culinary arts, it seems – a pie of some sort, yes?
It looks like a pizza, actually, Professor. But it's not flat like the ones at the Leaky Cauldron. It’s all puffed up.

Indeed, a pizza! A charming comfort food in the Muggle world, not unsimilar to a well-stuffed pumpkin pasty. But this variation is quite peculiar—almost like it has secret chambers within, much akin to the many hidden rooms of Hogwarts, don't you think?

I guess so. Maybe it’s one of those 'calzones' Aunt Petunia used to complain about when Dudley wanted something different. It does remind me a bit of the Room of Requirement, actually – looks normal on the outside, but there's a lot more to it once you dig in.

A delightful observation! The Room of Requirement indeed offers what one needs most, much as a good meal satisfies our hunger. It seems Muggles, too, have discovered ways to imbue their creations with surprises that cater to the cravings of the heart.
Do you think this is what it looks like to a Muggle when we talk about magical creatures or spellwork? Something they recognize, but... different, unexpected?

Precisely, Harry. To the well-organized mind, a new variation on an old favorite might not be befuddling but rather enlightening. It makes me wonder what other everyday wonders we fail to notice because they’re hidden in plain sight, by our expectations or our inattention.

Yeah, magic can be kind of like that. It's everywhere in the wizarding world, but you only really notice it when you're looking for it or when it surprises you. This 'calzone' might just be one of those little surprises in the Muggle world.

Indeed, my boy, magic, in its broadest sense, is about finding the extraordinary in the ordinary. Whether it be a spellbinding charm or the mastery of yeast and dough to create an appetizing meal – both require a sort of alchemy, do they not?

They do. And it's kind of funny to think of cooking as its own kind of potion-making. Mixing ingredients, hoping it turns out right... I'm not sure I'd be good at it without a proper potion master's guidance.

But that is where the adventure lies, Harry! The trials of the kitchen are not unlike those we face in life and magic – a pinch of risk, a dash of daring, and a healthy dollop of faith in one's own abilities. Shall we attempt to create our own magical version of this Muggle delicacy sometime?
I think that would be brilliant! Maybe we could even add our own magical twist to it. Although, I'm more likely to burn it than to turn it into anything edible.

But as with any potion, the process of creation is as valuable as the end result. Whether it turns out to be a gourmet delight or a new entry for Fred and George’s Skiving Snackboxes, it will be a process worth undertaking. After all, what is life but a series of attempts to fill it with moments of joy and discovery?

You're right, Professor. And if we do burn it, we'll just have to remember to have a laugh about it. I think that's something I've learned from you – no matter how dark things might get, there's always room for some light. Even if it's just from the sparks of a ruined calzone!

Light and levity, Harry, are often the best ingredients in any recipe, magical or not. And now, let us carry onward, ever mindful of the magic that awaits in the most unexpected of places. Now, back to our image. What do you suppose is inside that puffy exterior?
Tell me, Potter, what do you suppose these Muggles feel as they partake in their feast? There is something unmistakably common, yet peculiar about this gathering.
Well, Professor Snape, they look like they're having a good time, don't they? I mean, it reminds me a bit of the Great Hall during dinner, but less... magical.
Less magical, indeed. Notice the absence of moving portraits and enchanted ceilings. Yet, there's warmth, a silent enchantment found in their mundane camaraderie. Curious, isn't it?

It is. It makes you think that maybe you don't always need magic to have that sort of warmth. What's on their plates, though, that's another question. Doesn't look like anything the house elves would whip up.
Indeed, the complexity of potion-making is lost on such culinary... endeavors. Still, they find contentment in simplicity. Reflect on that, Potter. It's a lesson some wizards could stand to learn.
I guess you're right. There's something honest about it all. Just people, food, and conversation. No House points, no Quidditch rivalry, just... enjoying the moment.
A fleeting moment, much like life itself. Take it from one who has dwelled in shadows, Potter. Light, wherever you may find it, is worth savoring, even if it's by the dim glow of a Muggle's candle.
It's strange to hear you talk like that, sir. But I think I understand. We find light in different places, and it's important, isn't it?
It is of the essence, Potter. After all, darkness can be found in the midst of the brightest day, just as light can be found in the depths of night. Always.
Yeah... always.
Blimey, Harry, have a look at this! Is that a cow made out of chocolate?
It seems like it, Ron. I reckon someone's got a serious sweet tooth to dream up something this size.
Bet you anything Fred and George would have tried sneaking that into their dorm if we were back at Hogwarts. And I wouldn't mind helping!
I can just imagine the look on McGonagall's face catching you with a chocolate cow under your arm.
Worth it, though. But let's be real, it'd be a challenge getting through all that chocolate before it melts!
Definitely a challenge you'd be up for. Remember that time you tried to eat all those Chocolate Frogs on the train?
How could I forget? Nearly made myself sick, didn't I? And those cards... I was after Dumbledore, wasn't I?
And you ended up with about a dozen Ptolemys instead. Maybe we should stick to chocolate in smaller doses... like that chocolate bear next to it.
Nah, where's the fun in that? I'll tell you what, though, reckon we could share it with the rest of the gang. Hermione would raise her eyebrows so high, they'd disappear into her hairline.
She'd probably start lecturing us about sugar intake and proper dental hygiene while secretly wanting a piece.
Yeah, she's all talk, that one. But come on, Harry, could you imagine if this was a real magic shop item? What if it could moo?
Knowing our luck, it'd probably start mooing at the worst possible time... during an exam or something.
With our luck? Harry, you must be joking, it'd probably start a stampede right in the Great Hall.
"Mischief Managed," right? Anyway, let's agree we'd take down this chocolate cow together, Ron. It'd be just like one of our adventures, only tastier.
And with less running for our lives or dealing with Death Eaters, hopefully. Cheers to that, mate!
Cheers, Ron. Now, if only we could find a spell to shrink it down and sneak it back...
Accio mini chocolate cow! If only it were that simple...
Keep working on it, you'll crack that spell one day. But until then, we'll just have to dream.

Observe, Potter. Even here, amidst the dirt and squalor, the hierarchy of nature imposes its will. The crow, perched atop the cow, undisturbed. The dog, its coat marred by the harshness of its life, prowling below. What do you suppose this tableau represents?

It looks like survival, Professor. All of them are trying to get by in their own way. The crow's looking for food; the cow, it... doesn't seem to mind. And the dog, well, it's on the lookout for something, maybe scraps. It's rough, but they coexist somehow.

Coexistence, hmm? An interesting perspective. In the magical world, we often see the interdependence between different creatures as a metaphoric lesson. It is not unlike the relationships within Hogwarts, wouldn't you agree? Various houses, different students, each with their own role and purpose, yet bound together under a single banner.
I guess so. It's a bit like us, isn't it? Slytherins, Gryffindors; we all have our strengths, our struggles. And like these animals, we can get through a lot when we need to, when we work together.

A sentiment that sounds idealistically Gryffindor in nature, Potter. But your observation is not without merit. It is the very essence of survival, as you put it, that demands we recognize the significance of even the most disparate of connections.
And I suppose it's those connections that matter most. Like the cow and the crow—it might not be friendship, but there is a sort of silent understanding between them.
Indeed, Potter. Silent understandings often underpin the most complex of relationships. Take heed of that in your dealings, both within and beyond the walls of Hogwarts.
I will, Professor Snape. I think there's much more to understand, both for them and... for us.

Perhaps there is, Potter. Remain observant, and you will find that even the simplest creature has a story. Life, after all, is a tapestry of such tales, woven together by invisible threads of fate and circumstance.
I'll remember that. It seems like no matter where you look, there's always something to learn, even if it's from a cow, a crow, and a dog on a street.

Your capacity for drawing lessons from the mundane may yet prove to be a valuable trait, Potter. Now, shall we carry on? There are more lessons to be learned and, undoubtedly, more insights for you to uncover.
Take a moment, Harry, and observe this charming scene. What do you suppose this canine is pondering whilst perched upon that chair?
It looks a bit like it's waiting for someone, doesn't it, Professor? Maybe its owner, to come back.

Indeed, it does possess the patient demeanor of one in anticipation. Notice the sunlight bathing the room, touching upon the objects with a tranquil warmth - a room alive with memories, don't you think?
It feels really cozy and lived-in. Reminds me a bit of the Burrow, actually. Everything's a bit cluttered, but it just feels like home.

The Burrow, a place brimming with love and life. You see, much like this room, it is often the most unassuming of places that hold the deepest affection and comfort. The personal items, the haphazard stacks of books – each a testament to a life rich with stories.
I bet this dog has been part of plenty of stories too. Looks like the sort that's been on adventures, possibly chasing gnomes in the garden.

Quite the possibility. A creature of habit, loyal and brave, much like a certain young wizard I've had the pleasure to teach. Our four-legged companion here may also serve as a subtle reminder that companionship comes in many forms, wouldn't you agree?
Definitely. Sometimes I think about how much Hedwig meant to me. She was more than just an owl; she was a friend.

Indeed, Harry. And just like the love we bestow upon our friends, human or otherwise, it shapes us in ways we sometimes fail to realize until much later. It is reflected in the spaces we inhabit, the calmness in our hearts when we settle into a familiar nook.
You always know just what to say, Professor. It makes me think... even after everything's over, it's the small, quiet moments that really stick with you.
A profound truth, Harry. It is in the gentlest of moments that we often find the strength we need to face the tempests of our lives. Cherish these moments of peace, for they are rare and precious.
I will. I guess no matter where life takes me, I'll find joy in the little things... like a dog waiting on a chair.
And that is a lesson worth learning, Harry. For it is the little things that are of the greatest importance in the grand tapestry of life.
Potter, what do you suppose that sign could possibly require of any wizard who happens upon it? A command to halt one's progression seems like a quaint Muggle precaution at best.
It does look out of place here, doesn't it? I guess it's a Muggle way to make sure people don't run into trouble. A spell would probably do the job better, though.

Indeed. A simple Shield Charm could suffice for protection. Yet there is something undeniably... muggle about this that I find irritatingly charming. It's a physical warning—an artifact of the mundane.
I think there's something to be said for simplicity, though, don't you? Not everything has to be magical to work. Besides, sometimes the simplest solutions are the most effective.

Your naivety is endearing, Potter, if not a touch exasperating. Magical solutions are often synonymous with simplicity. Yet, I'll concede that in their world, Muggles manage with what they have, and sometimes, as begrudged as I am to admit it, they manage well.
I think both worlds have their strengths, Professor. After all, shouldn't we be looking for the best of both?

Philosophical musings from the famous Harry Potter. How exceedingly typical. Very well, let us ponder the strengths of both worlds. But remember, constant vigilance is required when amalgamating such disparate elements.

Mad-Eye would be proud to hear you say that. And you're right, it's all about balance. Now, about this sign—do you reckon it stops anything non-magical at all? Like a Muggle car, or maybe a runaway broomstick?
A runaway broomstick, Potter, would likely not abide by such a rudimentary signpost. As for Muggle automobiles, they seem to obey these decrepit symbols quite religiously.
Muggles do seem to like their rules. Maybe it's not as exciting as using magic, but there's a sort of order to it that's... reassuring, I suppose.

Reassuring, perhaps, to the uninitiated. But for those of us with a higher calling, we must aspire to more than mere order—we must strive for excellence. Let's hope, for your sake, you don't come across a 'Stop' sign in your future endeavors; I doubt 'reassuring' will be the sentiment you cling to.

Right, because my future endeavors are likely to be a lot more like the Triwizard Tournament than crossing the street. Still, sometimes a simple 'Stop' can make you think before you leap. Could be useful, that.

Caution, a trait you showed sparingly at Hogwarts, Potter. Nevertheless, as long as you recognize the value of foresight, there is hope for you yet. Now, shall we move on from this Muggle oddity? I have no desire to give it more attention than it warrants.
Curious, Potter, what one finds amusing about a photograph like this. The triviality of Muggle sustenance rituals. Does it not seem profoundly mundane to you?

I dunno, Professor. I think there's something quite comforting about it, actually. That's just a person enjoying a slice of pizza, something really normal and – I guess – something most people can relate to.
Comforting, you say? Yet here you stand, the vanquisher of Dark Lords, finding solace in an image of ordinary life. A poignant reminder of the world beyond our own, perhaps.
Yeah, exactly. Life isn’t always about fighting dark wizards and dangerous creatures. Sometimes it’s about the simple things, like enjoying a meal, even if it's something as Muggle as pizza.

Indeed, Potter, there is a lesson to be learned from even the most... pedestrian of subjects. It is the commonality, the shared human experience. As wizards, we must not become so detached from these moments lest we lose ourselves to the arrogance of our own power.

It's weird, but I think you'd probably get on with my cousin Dudley. He loves pizza. Food's all pretty simple when it comes down to it, isn't it? Kind of like potions, only you get to eat the end result.

A rather simplistic comparison, but not entirely inaccurate. The principles of combining ingredients to achieve a desired outcome – be it culinary or alchemical – are indeed universal. Though I assure you, Mr. Potter, my passion for potions far outweighs any interest in Muggle 'pizza'.
Maybe so, sir. But you've got to admit, there's something great about food bringing people together. Just like magic can in the right hands.

There will be no silly incantations over this meal, I assure you. But I concede the point, Potter. Sharing a meal can indeed be a... unifying experience. A momentary peace in an otherwise chaotic universe.
When you put it that way, Professor, it makes a lot of sense. I think it's something we can all agree on, magical or not.
Very well, Potter. It is perhaps a shared sentiment between us and the Muggles, the appreciation for a moment's peace. But remember, in our world, vigilance must accompany our rest – always.
